enrichment.AboutCourse:
QUALIFICATION OUTCOME\r
 \r
This course 2XW7 leads to QTS.  Further clarity on the significance of different teacher training qualifications can be found [here](http://www.wltsa.org.uk/initial-teacher-training/secondary-courses/different-qualification-outcomes/).\r
\r
SPECIAL FEATURES\r
This course is run by the West London Teaching School Alliance (WLTSA) as Provider (in partnership with (and accredited by) St Mary’s University, Twickenham.  \r
\r
WLTSA enables you to choose your host school at application.  Later, if there is a vacancy in your host school and they want to retain you, you can be employed fairly seamlessly for the following year without the post being advertised.  By becoming a WLTSA trainee, all our other secondary schools could also employ you this way and we operate a pool.\r
\r
Our aim is to produce exceptional teachers who can then remain in alliance schools, continuing to further their career with the benefit of our on-going CPD.\r
\r
THE TRAINING\r
\r
Most schools need you to be able to teach at least one of the three sciences to A-Level, and to be willing and able to teach all three Sciences at Key Stage 3 and ideally to GCSE.  We can help you learn to do so. \r
\r
Your training will be predominantly based in your host (employing) school other than\r
\r
*approx. 10 days at the university across the year; and\r
*your second placement for approx. 6 weeks at another WLTSA school.  \r
\r
You will register with the university and meet with your University Tutor who will begin to work with you on a needs analysis for a Training Plan. This will be reworked in term two and three between you, your school mentor and university tutor. \r
\r
Through an initial programme of observations, you will become familiar with the workings of the school and department (pupil groups, pastoral systems, staffing, curriculum, resources, facilities, methods of teaching, lesson planning, and assessment).  \r
\r
You will be treated like a member of staff and with your school mentors, you will feel supported as you become ready to teach. Our mentors are excellent experienced teachers who undertake rigorous training to develop their mentoring skills.  \r
\r
Throughout your time in both schools, your university tutor visits you to monitor your progress and discuss your development with you and your school mentors. You will maintain close links with your host school throughout the programme.\r
\r
You will have the opportunity to teach across KS3/KS4 and to support KS5.  KS3 topics include elements and chemical reactions, cell biology, nutrition and digestion, atoms, energy and forces.   \r
\r
\r
\r
enrichment.SalaryDetails:
The successful candidate in any maintained school would be paid a salary by the employing host school in line with the ‘Non-Qualified Teacher Pay Range 2019-20’, normally at the Point 1 level.  This government pay range is expected to be published in Aug/Sept. 2019.\r
\r
As a guide, Point 1 on the Unqualified Teacher Pay Range in 2017-18 was:\r
\r
* £20,909 (for a school in Inner London)\r
* £19,749 (for a school in outer London)\r
\r
One exception to this is Free Schools (such as The West London Free School) who set their own salary levels, usually fairly close to the government pay range. \r
\r
The tuition fee for this course will be covered by WLTSA.\r
Trainees on salaried programmes are not eligible for bursaries or student loans. \r
\r
Please note that we are unable to sponsor anyone who would otherwise not have the right to take up employment in this country. \r
enrichment.Qualifications:
* A scientific honours degree (2.2 or above) ideally in Physics.   \r
\r
* Two Sciences at A-Level.\r
\r
We may consider alternatively well-qualified mature candidates or those whose studies indicate breadth of scientific knowledge but early application is recommended because we may require you to attend a Physics Subject Knowledge Course before the teacher training begins.\r
\r
* Five GCSEs at least Grade C (or grade 5 for GCSEs sat in 2017 onwards) or the equivalent) including English Language and Mathematics.   \r
\r
* 'Pass’ in the [DfE Literacy and Numeracy Skills Tests](https://getintoteaching.education.gov.uk/how-to-apply/passing-the-skills-tests)\r
\r
Where appropriate, please read our guidance [Overseas Qualifications & GCSE Equivalency Tests](http://www.wltsa.org.uk/initial-teacher-training/secondary-courses/overseas-qualifications-gcse-equivalencies/).     \r
enrichment.InterviewProcess:
TWO STAGE INTERVIEW\r
\r
On receipt of your UCAS application this will be considered by the named host school, in collaboration with the WLTSA centrally and the university.  This process is administered by the WLTSA Teaching School office.\r
\r
If shortlisted for interview we will ask the university to invite you to an initial interview and we will email you to confirm the interview date (see [here](http://www.wltsa.org.uk/initial-teacher-training/secondary-courses/interview-dates/) and arrangements for the second interview which is held in the host school that you identified in your course choice on UCAS, normally approx. 3-4 days after the university interview.\r
\r
The university interviews are normally a full day, allowing time within this for their registry team to verify various identification documents and qualification certificates.  In addition to their panel interview, you may be required to undertake group tasks with other candidates and some subject knowledge testing.\r
\r
Assuming you pass at the university (which is common) the school interview would then be held (normally across a morning).  This would include a tour of the school; WLTSA literacy/numeracy tests; a classroom exercise and panel interview. \r
 \r
The WLTSA literacy and numeracy tests are quite separate to the DfE Skills tests referred to in the entry requirements below. Usually candidates have not taken the DfE skills tests when they come to interview and our own (very short) tests are used to help us identify those who may need to do more practice papers ahead of the skills tests and those who are unlikely to pass them.\r
\r
enrichment.OtherRequirements:
A level of maturity (irrespective of age) to operate as a responsible salaried member of staff.  \r
\r
A realistic understanding of the role of a teacher and some current issues facing the profession is important.   It can help to spend a couple of days observing relevant lessons in a state secondary school to strengthen your application but this observation is not a strict requirement.  [Top tips for getting observational experience](http://www.wltsa.org.uk/initial-teacher-training/secondary-courses/school-experience/).\r
\r
Offers are conditional on satisfactory outcome of a Disclosure & Barring Service check (£52) and an occupational health check (£20) both administered through the university after an offer is accepted.   \r
enrichment.PersonalQualities:
We want you to have passion and enthusiasm.  We need trainees who can engage and inspire students to a love of learning, who are:   \r
*committed to championing their students;\r
*open to learn about children’s physical/social/emotional/cognitive needs and how these can affect behaviour;\r
*in good health with the ability to cope with stress.  Teaching is incredibly rewarding, but it also requires an element of resilience!\r
*professional and committed to equal opportunities;\r
*able to communicate well in written/spoken English, with at least basic computer skills and commitment to developing these.\r
*have a sense of humour and an ability to laugh at yourself.     \r
enrichment.HowSchoolPlacementsWork:
With WLTSA you select the main host school at application but on this particular salaried course we only have one school offering a salaried place.  We then later arrange your second placement at another contrasting WLTSA school to provide greater depth to your training experience. \r
\r
While there is only one salaried Physics place, please be assured that schools are NOT inundated with applications for Physics.  We commonly interview individually whenever a good application is received. You can always ring up to ask how many people (if any) are being considered by the school at the point that you are about to apply.  \r
\r
The school seeking trainees on this particular salaried Physics course is\r
 \r
* West London Free School, W6 9LP\r
\r
You can read descriptions of each of these schools in our overall [WLTSA Secondary School Summary Descriptions](http://www.wltsa.org.uk/initial-teacher-training/secondary-courses/wltsa-secondary-school-summary-descriptions/).    Our [Map of WLTSA Schools](http://www.wltsa.org.uk/map-of-all-wltsa-schools/) may also be helpful.\r
\r
Please be aware that we have other [WLTSA secondary courses](http://www.wltsa.org.uk/initial-teacher-training/secondary-courses/secondary-course-vacancies-2019-20-cohort/) at other schools including a separate Unsalaried Physics programme (2XW6). DfE bursaries for chemistry on unsalaried programmes are so high as to make them financially compatible, with salaried programmes. You can apply to both the salaried and unsalaried courses at the same time across a wider range of schools.\r
\r
You can make three choices overall when you apply.\r
\r
THE TECHNICAL BIT!\r
\r
You don’t have to restrict yourself to one school within a course, but each school would count as one application and you get three choices overall in Round 1.  Please also be aware that we have so many partner schools that we have been forced to split artificially on UCAS into three provider names.  See [How to apply & how to choose more than one school on a course.](http://www.wltsa.org.uk/initial-teacher-training/secondary-courses/how-to-apply-how-to-choose-more-than-1-school-on-a-course/)\r
\r
BE STRATEGIC WHEN YOU APPLY\r
\r
You can always ring us up to ask how many applications (if any) are being considered by different schools at the point that you are about to apply.  We also keep our website up to date so that you can see which schools have already shortlisted and are interviewing. \r
\r
We commonly interview individually whenever a good application is received. \r

inst.TrainWithUs:
WHO ARE WE? \r
\r
We are a large alliance of 60 schools: nurseries, primaries, special needs, secondaries, sixth forms; faith and non-faith, maintained schools, independent schools and free schools.   We have formal partnership arrangements with three universities.\r
\r
Most of our schools are in Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington & Chelsea, but we also have schools in Westminster; Richmond; Ealing, Hounslow, Hillingdon and Southwark. \r
\r
The central Teaching School Office for WLTSA is based at Sacred Heart High School, in Hammersmith. \r
\r
OUR APPROACH TO TRAINEE RECRUITMENT\r
 \r
We pride ourselves in the support that we provide potential applicants and in the speed of our shortlisting. We have a detailed website which is a good place to start.  We also hold fortnightly [information sessions](http://www.wltsa.org.uk/initial-teacher-training/secondary-courses/recruitment-events-open-days/) to explain the qualifications;  routes into teaching; finance; and how to secure a place!  \r
\r
 ‘That’s the first time that I have ever properly understood it all. Brilliant!’  Applicant 2018.\r
\r
The Teaching School Office is staffed full time with experts to talk to on the phone. \r
\r
You choose the schools when you apply. If you perform well but fail to get a place at your preferred school, we continue to work with you, recommending you to other WLTSA schools of your choice rather than rejecting you.\r
\r
We place significant emphasis on getting a good fit between trainee and school because we are all keenly focused on recruitment for qualified teachers in our alliance schools the following year.\r
\r
[Further opportunities to develop your career with WLTSA](http://www.wltsa.org.uk/initial-teacher-training/career-path1/)\r
inst.TrainWithDisability:
WLTSA and all our partner universities are committed to supporting students with disabilities. Please contact us as early as possible in your application process so that your needs are met and support can be arranged.\r
\r
You can also find support and information from the university accrediting the course that you hope to apply for:\r
\r
ST MARY'S UNIVERSITY offers advice and support to their students who have requirements as a result of a disability, specific learning difficulty (e.g. dyslexia), medical condition or temporary disability, such as injury.  St Mary’s Dyslexia and Disability Co-ordinator (DDC) works closely with the other members of the Student Services team, supporting students in their time at university assisting them to be proactive in their studies as an independent learner.  [http://www.smuc.ac.uk/student-support/dyslexia-and-disability/](http://www.smuc.ac.uk/student-support/dyslexia-and-disability/)\r
\r
UNIVERSITY OF ROEHAMPTON: [http://www.roehampton.ac.uk/Disabilities/Support/](http://www.roehampton.ac.uk/Disabilities/Support/)\r
\r
UCL: School Direct students are entitled to support from the UCL Student Support and Wellbeing (SSW) team. You can find more information here:- \r
[https://www.ucl.ac.uk/students/disability-support](https://www.ucl.ac.uk/students/disability-support)\r

AccreditingProviderEnrichments.Description:
This WLTSA course is accredited by University of Roehampton, who have been at the forefront of teacher education for over 100 years.  Many members of staff are at the cutting edge of research in teacher education, which has a positive impact on the quality of our provision; tutors have extensive teaching experience in schools with many having served as consultants or as Ofsted inspectors.\r
\r
The university experience is enhanced by its beautiful campus - unique in being both close to central London and set in parkland with grand, historic buildings and lakes side by side with newly built modern facilities.\r

This WLTSA course is accredited by St Mary's University, Twickenham. \r
\r
In 2000, St Mary’s celebrated 150 years in Education. With just under 4,000 students training to teach on primary and secondary, they are now London’s second largest teacher training course provider and in 2011, St Mary’s was deemed to be ‘outstanding’ by OfSTED during inspection. \r
\r
Course tutors at St Mary’s are all skilful teachers themselves, with many years of experience in schools and higher education.  Schools in the Alliance have excellent relationships with the university.\r

This WLTSA course is accredited by UCL (Institute of Education) which has been providing first-class teacher training, in partnership with schools and colleges for over 100 years.  UCL (IOE) graduates are highly sought after in schools and colleges throughout London and the UK. \r
Its central location in historic Bloomsbury means that you will be studying in the heart of London. The London Underground station at Russell Square is minutes from the main building and King’s Cross, St Pancras and Euston stations are also close by.\r
\r
You can view UCL’s online teacher training prospectus is here: \r
[https://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/teacher-training-programmes](https://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/teacher-training-programmes)\r
